column13: We are also committed to further understanding the barriers impacting homeowners when purchasing insurance through our Financial Inclusion Action Plan1 leadership commitment. column13: Suncorp has strongly advocated for the Bundaberg Flood Levee Project over several years. This year, the Queensland and Federal governments announced funding for the levee, which, when built, could see affected locals save around $1,000 a year on their home insurance premiums.

column13: We have continued to invest in technology to protect customers. This year, we have added new warning messages in the Suncorp Secured Two Factor App and in our SMS one-time codes to encourage customers to stop and think before they are tricked into giving codes to offenders. We also deployed an extension to our behavioural and detection analytics systems, enabling our teams to detect when customers operate their Internet banking while their computer is remotely accessed.

column13: This year, AAMI introduced a new Driver Rewards feature on its app, which delivered an enhanced telematics customer experience and has demonstrated a powerful ability to improve individual driving behaviours. Since launch, over 70,000 customers have registered and had over 80,000,000 kilometres of driving data analysed and communicated back, leading to greater road safety awareness and responsibility.

column13: Suncorp and the Foundation for Rural & Regional Renewal (FRRR) awarded a further 27 grants in FY23 to local community groups affected by the 2022 East Coast Floods. With a combined worth of $500,000, the grants funded projects to see communities better equipped to manage future natural disasters. The next round of grants awarded in FY24 will help communities impacted by the 2022/23 Victorian floods.
column20: Foundation for Rural & Regional Renewal, East Coast Floods, Future Natural Disasters

column8: Solar powered batteries for Mooloolah Valley

To help the community prepare for future disaster events, the Mooloolah Valley Community Association used a $25,000 grant to purchase and install three batteries that can be used to supply power to the region. The batteries have kept the communityÃ¢ÂÂs ability running during the two electricity outages that Mooloolah has experienced since the batteries were installed.

The partnership continues AAMIÃ¢ÂÂs proud history of supporting community programs that spearhead positive change. The partners hosted their first event earlier this year. column13: Suncorp has continued its work with partner First Nations Foundation, running financial literacy programs for 819 Indigenous Australians in FY23 and training 246 mentors to deliver the program locally. A key achievement was the launch of a new training module called Reconciliation: It Starts with Understanding, which more than 300 employees have completed since its launch in August 2022.

column13: Suncorp has policies, systems, processes and people in place to identify, assess, manage and monitor internal and external sources of material risk. Effective risk and compliance management is supported by: ÃÂ an Enterprise Risk Management Framework, through which the Board sets the direction of risk management ÃÂ a sound risk culture, aligned to SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs broader culture ÃÂ a Risk Appetite Statement that is aligned to the Suncorp strategy and sets out the nature and degree of risk the Board is willing to accept in the pursuit of business objectives ÃÂ the Three Lines of Defence Model and clear accountabilities with risk owned in the first line ÃÂ an independent Risk function that oversees and challenges the business in our risk-taking, and drives SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs Risk Strategy, and ÃÂ the Board Risk Committee which monitors management of existing and emerging risks to the business.

column13: SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs Enterprise Risk Management Framework (ERMF) applies to Suncorp, including all of the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs regulated entities, setting out the minimum standards to manage the risks that Suncorp is exposed to as it implements our strategic and business objectives and ÃÂ roles and responsibilities, including the Three Lines of Defence Model for risk management accountability. SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs ERMF lays the foundation for the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs approach to risk management and evolves with the business strategy and operating environment. The framework provides a holistic approach to risk management with all financial, nonÃ¢ÂÂfinancial and strategic risks covered and outlined by risk categories. The ERMF sets out accountabilities, governance arrangements and processes for managing risk within the Three Lines of Defence Model.

column13: The Three Lines of Defence Model supports our risk-taking through clarity of ownership and independent oversight with the clear expectation that All business areas (the First Line of Defence) are responsible for managing their risks. The First Line of Defence owns their risks and compliance with policies, frameworks, standards and risk appetite. ÃÂ The Risk function forms the independent Second Line of Defence team that defines the risk and compliance management approach, policies, frameworks, standards and processes. They support the business in our risk-taking through advice, oversight and practical challenges. ÃÂ Internal and External Audits are the Third Line of Defence and provide independent reporting to the Board Audit Committee and Risk Committee.
column20: Three Lines of Defence Model, Risk Function Forms, Second Line of Defence Team

Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column7: Suncorp is committed to high standards of ethical behaviour, and we expect our people to always behave in a manner consistent with our values and code of conduct. We recognise that behaviours that lead to Bribery and Corruption have an adverse effect on customers, shareholders, and communities wherever they occur. Suncorp requires compliance with all Anti-Bribery and Corruption laws in all markets and jurisdictions in which it operates or conducts transactions.

column8: Due Diligence on its Third Parties
column13: Suncorp must know who it is doing business with and who is conducting business on its behalf. Suncorp must undertake appropriate due diligence before engaging Third Parties, making donations, entering business relationships with, or acquiring other entities. Suncorp must ensure that all gifts and entertainment, payments to Third Parties, or fees for other goods and services are proportionate and appropriate, in line with community expectations, and recorded in line with the Conflict of Interest Policy where applicable.

The information provided in this report has been sourced from a combination of lodged income tax returns, financial records, audited financial statements, payroll data and other tax lodgements for Australia and New Zealand. Unless otherwise stated, all data has been prepared for 1 July 2021 to 30 June 2022. Data related to taxes paid or collected are reported on an accruals/incurred basis, referred to as the relevant period. Total tax contribution data in this report is included only for Suncorp Group Limited and its 100 per cent owned subsidiaries. However, taxes borne and collected by companies within Suncorp Group that are non-wholly-owned subsidiaries are excluded from this report.1 All payments are reported in Australian dollars, Suncorp 1, except for 68 %-owned AA Insurance Limited in New Zealand. GroupÃ¢ÂÂs functional and presentation currency. Payments included in this report have been rounded to the nearest million dollars ($m).

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column7: Formal risk management procedures incorporating tax include the Enterprise Risk Management Framework. Ã¢ÂÂ Risk Appetite Statement. Ã¢ÂÂ Corporate Governance Statement. Ã¢ÂÂ Tax guidelines relating to taxes, tax concessions and relationships with regulators. Ã¢ÂÂ Tax Risk Management and Governance Standard. Ã¢ÂÂ Significant Transaction Identification and Tax Risk Escalation Guideline. Ã¢ÂÂ Quarterly tax compliance papers submitted to the Board Audit Committee. These formal mechanisms are complemented by informal, day-to-day procedures to manage tax risk. These include management obligations to Ã¢ÂÂ provide an appropriately resourced tax function with experienced professionals who care about tax risks through regular tax reporting and associated internal controls, Ã¢ÂÂ implement mechanisms to measure significant transactions, materiality, and risk, Ã¢ÂÂ provide tax engagement protocols, Ã¢ÂÂ engage external tax advisors where necessary and adhere to SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs group-wide governance policies, and Ã¢ÂÂ obtain tax rulings from the relevant regulators on complex or uncertain areas of the law.
